description.plain:
Tariq “Black Thought” Trotter is the co-founder and MC of the legendary Philadelphia-based hip-hop group The Roots.

Thought is highly renowned in the Hip-Hop community for his socially aware, informed, and character-driven rap style. He is considered by many, a lyrical killer and legend that falls in the same category as Yasiin Bey, Talib Kweli, Q-Tip, members of the Wu-Tang Clan and even Nas.

He also is a member and founder of supergroup Money Making Jam Boys, consisting of Black, and other Roots collaborators Sugar-Tongue-Slim (STS), Greg Porn, Truck North, and Dice Raw.  STS can be heard on “Right On” while the other three are widely and largely on Undun.

songs.full_title: Black Thought Freestyles on Flex | Freestyle #087 by Black Thought
songs.title: Black Thought Freestyles on Flex | Freestyle #087
songs.title_with_featured: Black Thought Freestyles on Flex | Freestyle #087

description.plain:
Black Thought’s 10-minute, 2000+ word freestyle on Hot 97 became viral quickly, earning over a million views in 24 hours and holding 12.8+ million views as of March 17th 2021, making it one of the most viewed Funk Flex freestyles of all time.

Not only does he display his immense skills and erudition, but he explores his life and struggles as a black man in the United States. He goes further by elaborating on his role as a black rapper, combining the literary with the militant.

What most likely led to the freestyle garnering so much attention, however, is his critique of contemporary rappers, namely of the “mumble rap” variety. His blend of history, literature, and street knowledge along with reverence for older rappers creates the foundation for his argument. He calls on current rappers to have a purpose with their music, to fight for something instead of fueling the decay of a culture.

songs.full_title: Twofifteen by Black Thought
songs.title: Twofifteen

description.plain: “Twofifteen” is a nod to Philadelphia’s area code, which on some level next to Afro-Intellectualism, is the greatest influence on his present day output. Listening to Black Thought rap about his love of “illadel” is like witnessing a person live in one setting their whole life, except in the case of Black Thought, he’s tapped into universal, almost Sufic knowledge.

Who the technical culprit? I don't mess with no vultures
I'm electrical voltage, not the regular dosage
Too obsessive compulsive, I'm a fuckin' explosive
Mixed message in a bottle, I left with the postman
I'm that arachnophobia, black petroleum

Ain't a damn thing really changed as far as I can tell it

Look like a couple of days before the doctor comin'

I think the world tryna sock it to me
It kinda feel like everything is out of pocket for me
Who keep it a hundred when everything's partial?
Dignity and sanity is what the game cost you
Wake up to the paddles on your chest, we had lost you
I'm just paintin' a picture like Kerry James Marshall

songs.full_title: 9th vs. Thought by Black Thought
songs.title: 9th vs. Thought

description.plain: Anthropology is the study of humans, and as the first interlude suggests, it takes two components to make it: the student and the study – someone who studies human behavior, and someone who is the human object of study. These two elements seem to be 9th Wonder’s beat and Black Thought’s verses. Here, Black Thought is putting on a rap clinic and being braggadocious about his lyricism and style in a masterful way.

songs.full_title: Dostoyevsky by Black Thought (Ft. Rapsody)
songs.title: Dostoyevsky

description.plain:
“Dostoyevsky” alludes to the intelligence of Russian philosopher Fyodor Dostoyevsky, and how Black Thought, Rapsody, and 9th Wonder plan to bring that type of wisdom to the rap universe.

Thought and Rapsody previously collaborated on “Nobody” in 2017, which was also produced by 9th Wonder.

songs.full_title: Making a Murderer by Black Thought (Ft. Styles P)
songs.title: Making a Murderer

description.plain:
Just a day after an interview detailed some of his anticipated upcoming collaborations, Roots emcee Black Thought premieres this track that is a play on the recently popular Netflix series of the same name. Produced by 9th Wonder and featuring Styles P, it is quite clear that the three are fully complicit in killing mediocrity, in lyrics and in beats.

9th Wonder samples Thai singer Hongthong Daoudon’s “Isan” for this beat:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RvUapcqDWak

songs.title: Good Morning
songs.title_with_featured: Good Morning (Ft. Killer Mike, Pusha T & Swizz Beatz)

description.plain:
Lyrical superpowers Black Thought, Pusha T, and Killer Mike team up for “Good Morning,” with Swizz Beatz serving as the hype-man and Sean C handling the production.

On the star-studded song, the trio of rappers delivers three thought-provoking and introspective verses. Black Thought and Killer Mike address black issues in their lyrics, while Pusha T raps a menacing verse focusing on ego-trip.

“Good Morning” is the first single from Black Thought’s October 2020 solo album Streams of Thought Vol. 3: Cain and Abel, which was delayed in July in the wake of the tragic passing of The Roots co-founder Malik B.

songs.full_title: Get Outlined by Black Thought
songs.title: Get Outlined

description.plain:
Black Thought has returned, and with him comes another dose of bars to unpack. It might be the closest we’ve come to Thought dropping knowledge on the state of the game; in true fashion, we’re left to infer his deeper message through the surrounding stanzas.

Behind the boards, Salaam Remi delivers a simple backdrop, evocative of the golden-era aesthetic. A rolling bassline loops over breakbeats, emphasized by muted guitar hits and Ron Burgundy-esque Jazz Flutes. Hardly flashy, but more than effective for the purpose of lyrical dexterity.

songs.title_with_featured: Welcome to America (Ft. Angela Hunte & C. S. Armstrong)

description.plain: Welcome to America is basically talking about The American dream which is the belief that anyone, regardless of where they were born or what class they were born into, can attain their own version of success in a society where upward mobility is possible for everyone. The American dream is achieved through sacrifice, risk-taking, and hard work, rather than by chance.
